resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
paleolimbot opened a new pull request #12633:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12633


   As noted in ARROW-15929, we have code referring to the wrong thread pool (i.e., `arrow::io_thread_count()` and `arrow::set_io_thread_count()` are actually setting the number of cores used instead of the actual thread count). This appears to have been an inadvertent addition changed in ARROW-12760 (#10316).
   
   ``` r
   # remotes::install_github("apache/arrow/r")
   library(arrow, warn.conflicts = FALSE)
   
   cpu_count()
   #> [1] 8
   set_io_thread_count(4)
   cpu_count()
   #> [1] 4
   ```
   
   This PR switches that so that we're referring to the correct thread pool:
   
   ``` r
   # remotes::install_github("paleolimbot/arrow/r@r-thread-io-pool-count")
   library(arrow, warn.conflicts = FALSE)
   
   cpu_count()
   #> [1] 8
   set_io_thread_count(4)
   cpu_count()
   #> [1] 8
   io_thread_count()
   #> [1] 4
   ```


--

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #12633:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12633#discussion_r827123086



##########
File path: r/R/config.R
##########
@@ -26,7 +26,9 @@ cpu_count <- function() {
 #' @param num_threads integer: New number of threads for thread pool
 #' @export
 set_cpu_count <- function(num_threads) {
+  current_cpu_count <- cpu_count()
   SetCpuThreadPoolCapacity(as.integer(num_threads))
+  invisible(current_cpu_count)

Review comment:
       Out of curiosity, what does `invisible` do?




--

paleolimbot commented on a change in pull request #12633:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12633#discussion_r827141958



##########
File path: r/R/config.R
##########
@@ -26,7 +26,9 @@ cpu_count <- function() {
 #' @param num_threads integer: New number of threads for thread pool
 #' @export
 set_cpu_count <- function(num_threads) {
+  current_cpu_count <- cpu_count()
   SetCpuThreadPoolCapacity(as.integer(num_threads))
+  invisible(current_cpu_count)

Review comment:
       It just keeps the value from being printed by default!
   
   ``` r
   f <- function() {
     invisible(5)
   }
   
   g <- function() {
     5
   }
   
   f()
   g()
   #> [1] 5
   
   #...you can force printing with ()
   (f())
   #> [1] 5
   
   # most global option setting works like this in R
   par(cex = 23)
   (par(cex = 23))
   #> $cex
   #> [1] 23
   ```
   




--

+test_that("set_io_thread_count() sets the number of io threads", {
+  current_io_thread_count <- io_thread_count()
+  on.exit(set_io_thread_count(current_io_thread_count))

Review comment:
       Didn't know about `on.exit`. Cool!

paleolimbot commented on a change in pull request #12633:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12633#discussion_r828279264



##########
File path: r/R/config.R
##########
@@ -40,5 +42,7 @@ io_thread_count <- function() {
 #' @param num_threads integer: New number of threads for thread pool
 #' @export
 set_io_thread_count <- function(num_threads) {
+  current_io_thread_count <- io_thread_count()
   SetIOThreadPoolCapacity(as.integer(num_threads))
+  invisible(current_io_thread_count)

Review comment:
       That was the idea...many other options setting things do this in R (although if it's confusing it's easy to remove it).
   
   ``` r
   (par(cex = 23))
   #> $cex
   #> [1] 1
   (options(width = 123))
   #> $width
   #> [1] 80
   ```
   




--

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12633#discussion_r828306668



##########
File path: r/R/config.R
##########
@@ -40,5 +42,7 @@ io_thread_count <- function() {
 #' @param num_threads integer: New number of threads for thread pool
 #' @export
 set_io_thread_count <- function(num_threads) {
+  current_io_thread_count <- io_thread_count()
   SetIOThreadPoolCapacity(as.integer(num_threads))
+  invisible(current_io_thread_count)

Review comment:
       Yeah I actually had to spend a couple minutes parsing the tests to understand that was intended behavior. Maybe it's worth rewriting the tests to make that more obvious. For example, rewrite
   
   ```r
   expect_identical(set_io_thread_count(1), current_io_thread_count)
   ```
   
   to
   
   ```r
   previous_count <- set_io_thread_count(1)
   expect_identical(previous_count, current_io_thread_count)
   ```
   




--

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
[https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/5cb5afc40547b4f75739e31ff8632c71a10d3084/r/src/threadpool.cpp#L51-L57]

This accidentally references the wrong pool.
fields.summary: [R] io_thread_count is actually the CPU thread count

comments.body: Is there any way to access that value? I see https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/2863fdd0e8828605c17b565dcd18672f2e49ce1f/cpp/src/arrow/io/util_internal.h#L52-L53, but I don't see a way to access it from the R bindings (the util_internal.h header isn't there, which I assume is probably a good thing?).

{noformat}
> library(arrow)

Attaching package: ‘arrow’

The following object is masked from ‘package:utils’:

    timestamp

> arrow::io_thread_count()
[1] 16
{noformat}
from config.R
